metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of LAI measurements in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas
metadata.description:
The dataset of LAI measurements was obtained by LI-3000, the protractor and the ruler in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas on May, 20, 24, 25, 28 and 31, Jun. 6, 11, 12, 14, 16, 21 and 27, Jul. 2 and 9, 2008.
     The maximum leaf length and width of maize and wheat, the leaf angle, length and width of each section (one leaf was divided into 3 sections) were measured. And also the plant height, leaf base height, the crop spacing, the canopy height, row spacing and ridge spacing were measured. Two representative plants would be taken back for indoor observation for the stem length, stem width, stem circumference, and leaf area by LAI3000. Data were archived in Excel format.

background: Leaf area index (LAI) is one of the important geometric-structure parameters in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems. Accurate LAI retrieval is always a key task of such remote-sensing applications, and it is also a precondition of crop-yield estimation, vegetative evapotranspiration calculation and the energy-exchange evaluation of terrestrial vegetation (Badhwar et al., 1986; Townshend et al., 1988; Baret et al., 1991; Wood et al., 1993; Bonan, 1995; Bicheron et al., 1999; Buermann et al., 2001; Kamalesh et al., 2008). In general, there are three categories of LAI retrieval methods. The first category is experiential inversion method based on Vegetation Index (VI), such as retrieving LAI according to the correlation between the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and LAI (Turner, 1999; Brown et al., 2000; Haboudane et al., 2004; Wang et al., 2005). Although such an approach is simple and widely-used, its accuracy is very low, and some VI can easily get saturated. The second category can be called the reflectance model inversion method, by which the anisotropic effect caused by sun-object-sensor geometry can be removed, but the effect caused by background variations cannot be avoided, especially within mixed pixels. The complex background inhibits accurate LAI retrieval (Li et al., 1986; Nilson et al., 1989; Chen et al., 1997; Xu, 2005).
research objective: Based on a hybrid canopy reflectance model, a new hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is proposed in this paper. This method can estimate LAI accurately through analyzing the canopy anisotropy. The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
challenges: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions constitute three factors that can strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. As the derivative method is very sensitive to random noise, we put forward an innovative filtering approach, by which the data can be de-noised in spectral and spatial dimensions synchronously.
methods: After the pre-processing procedures, the DSD method was applied, and the retrieved LAI was validated by ground reference data at 11 sites.
dataset: The study region was situated in Zhangye, Gansu Province, China; hyperspectral and multi-angular images of the study region were acquired via the Compact High-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer/Project for On-Board Autonomy (CHRIS/PROBA), on 4 June 2008.
findings: Results show that the new LAI inversion method is accurate and effective with the aid of the innovative filtering method.

background: Gross primary production (GPP) is defined as the overall rate of fixation of carbon through the process of vegetation photosynthesis. It is used to quantify the amount of biomass produced within an ecosystem over a unit of time, regardless of the amount of respiration. The seasonal difference of GPP and ecosystem respiration (Re) determines the net ecosystem exchange (NEE) of CO2 between the atmosphere and forest ecosystems and is important for understanding global carbon cycle climate change research. The eddy covariance (EC) technique is one of the best micrometeorological methods for the estimation of CO2, water, and energy exchange between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. Satellite remote sensing provides consistent and systematic land surface observations and has played an increasing role in characterizing vegetation structure and estimating GPP. The fundamental methodology of GPP estimation is based on Monteith’s equation: GPP ¼ LUE /C2 fAPAR /C2 PAR, where LUE is the light use efficiency, often in units of mol CO2 per mol photosynthetic photon flux density (mol CO2 mol−1 PPFD), and fAPAR represents the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (PAR). Many models and methods using the LUE basis have been proposed for GPP estimation from ground measurements and satellite remote sensing data.
research objective: In this study, the daily MODIS surface reflectance product was selected for midday GPP estimation because MODIS can provide daily coverage of the study sites with an acceptable ground resolution and the required spectral characteristics. On the basis of previous research, we selected some VIs that were proved to have the potential to estimate LUE (mol CO2 mol−1 PPFD) and fAPAR and proposed a method to estimate GPP (mg CO2 m−2 s−1) with the MODIS data. The study should be helpful for future GPP models driven by all remote‐sensing inputs.
challenges: However, besides the difficulty of partitioning the respiration of ecosystems into autotrophic respiration and heterotrophic respiration, the EC only provides integrated CO2 flux measurements over footprints with sizes and shapes that vary with the tower height, canopy physical characteristics, and wind velocity. The limitation of LUE models, however, is that they require meteorological inputs that are often not available at sufficiently detailed temporal and spatial scales, resulting in substantial errors in the outputs. Estimates of daytime Re from the nighttime RE‐T relation are associated with considerable uncertainties such as the overestimation of daytime respiration due to the extrapolation of nighttime respiration fluxes.
methods: In this study, we evaluated the broadband MODIS VIs for the LUE and fAPAR estimation and tried to understand the mechanism of our GPP estimation methodology. When we estimated GPP using the expression VI × VI × PAR, the determination coefficients R2 largely improved (R2 = 0.81 to 0.91), indicating that GPP can be well estimated with MODIS.
dataset: The study sites were located outside the city of Zhangye, Gansu Province, in western China. All measurements were taken from 10 June to 13 July 2008. The maize was planted in early May 2008 in the typical solonetzic soil of western China with relatively sufficient nutrition and water supplies. To form a suite of data, the product (MOD 09, 500 m) of the Terra MODIS surface‐reflectance atmospheric correction algorithm from 13 June to 10 July 2008 was downloaded to estimate the midday GPP at the satellite overpass time. After selection, 16 cloud‐free days of data were used to develop our method for GPP estimation.
findings: EVI × EVI × PAR provided the best estimation of GPP with the highest R2 of 0.91 because EVI was found to be the best indicator of both LUE and fAPAR (R2 of 0.87 and 0.76, respectively).

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure leaf area index (LAI) in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to measure leaf area index (LAI) involves using instruments like the LAI3000, along with tools such as protractors and rulers. These are used to measure the maximum length and width of each leaf, leaf inclination angles, and canopy height, among other parameters, in vegetation like maize and wheat.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced in LAI retrieval using remote sensing methods?
Example.Answer: A challenge in LAI retrieval using remote sensing methods is the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, which can affect accuracy. Variations in background characteristics and atmospheric conditions further constrain the retrieval process. The use of hyperspectral directional second derivative methods can help address some of these challenges by analyzing canopy anisotropy.

Definition.Question: What does 'leaf area index (LAI)' mean in the context of terrestrial vegetation ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Leaf area index (LAI) is one of the important geometric-structure parameters in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems. It is essential for accurate LAI retrieval in remote-sensing applications and is a precondition for crop-yield estimation, vegetative evapotranspiration calculation, and the energy-exchange evaluation of terrestrial vegetation.

Definition.Question: What is the 'hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD)' in terms of LAI estimation?
Definition.Answer: The hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) is a technique proposed to estimate LAI accurately by analyzing the canopy anisotropy using a hybrid canopy reflectance model. This method involves innovative filtering to de-noise data in spectral and spatial dimensions, improving LAI retrieval accuracy.

Definition.Question: What does 'Gross Primary Production (GPP)' refer to in ecosystem studies?
Definition.Answer: Gross Primary Production (GPP) is defined as the overall rate of carbon fixation through vegetation photosynthesis. It quantifies the amount of biomass produced in an ecosystem over time, without accounting for respiration, and is crucial for understanding the net ecosystem exchange of CO2 and the global carbon cycle.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for leaf area index (LAI) using ground-based instruments compare to those using remote sensing techniques?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based methods involve direct measurements using instruments like LAI3000, protractors, and rulers to obtain detailed structural parameters of vegetation, which are precise but limited in spatial coverage. In contrast, remote sensing techniques, such as those using hyperspectral and multi-angular images, offer broader spatial coverage and the ability to analyze canopy anisotropy, but may face challenges like canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variability affecting accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of instruments like LAI3000, protractors, and rulers impact the accuracy and reliability of data collected for leaf area index in various vegetation settings?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of instruments such as LAI3000, protractors, and rulers can provide detailed measurements of vegetation structure parameters, such as leaf length, width, and angle, contributing to high accuracy and reliability in the data collected for leaf area index. These tools allow researchers to capture precise geometric properties of leaves, which are critical for understanding vegetation canopy structure and dynamics in different settings.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the variability in canopy reflectance anisotropy and background characteristics affect the retrieval of leaf area index and how can innovative filtering methods address these issues?
Interpretation.Answer: Variability in canopy reflectance anisotropy and background characteristics can lead to inaccuracies in leaf area index retrieval by introducing noise and complicating reflectance model inversion. Innovative filtering methods, which de-noise data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, can help to address these issues by removing random noise and enhancing the clarity and precision of the retrieved data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the variability in accuracy when retrieving leaf area index (LAI) from remote sensing data in mixed vegetation environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and variability in atmospheric conditions are factors that can strongly constrain the accuracy of retrieved LAI. The complex background inhibits accurate LAI retrieval, especially within mixed pixels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do some methods for estimating gross primary production (GPP) using satellite data encounter substantial errors?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Substantial errors in GPP estimation from satellite data arise because LUE models require meteorological inputs that are often not available at sufficiently detailed temporal and spatial scales. Additionally, estimates of daytime ecosystem respiration from nighttime respiration measurements are associated with considerable uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes low accuracy in experiential inversion methods based on Vegetation Index (VI) for LAI retrieval?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The experiential inversion methods based on Vegetation Index (VI) for LAI retrieval have low accuracy because such approaches are simple and widely-used but can easily result in saturation of some VIs, leading to inaccurate results.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on LAI retrieval accuracy when using hyperspectral directional second derivative methods combined with innovative filtering techniques?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Results show that the new LAI inversion method is accurate and effective with the aid of the innovative filtering method, overcoming challenges such as canopy reflectance anisotropy and random noise.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the application of MODIS surface reflectance products influence the estimation of Gross Primary Production (GPP) in agricultural settings?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The estimation of GPP using MODIS surface reflectance products, specifically through the expression VI × VI × PAR, showed improved determination coefficients, indicating that such an approach can accurately estimate GPP in agricultural settings.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of measuring leaf area index (LAI) using both ground reference data and remote sensing data in terms of data validation and method reliability?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By using ground reference data to validate LAI retrieved from remote sensing data, such as hyperspectral and multi-angular images, the method's reliability and accuracy can be enhanced, helping to address constraints like canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of utilizing traditional measurement tools such as rulers and angle meters in the data collection process for vegetation structure parameters?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of utilizing traditional measurement tools like rulers and angle meters is to obtain precise measurements of vegetation structure parameters, such as leaf length, width, and inclination. These measurements are essential for calculating the leaf area index (LAI), which is crucial for understanding various ecological and agricultural processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to apply innovative filtering approaches in the hyperspectral directional second derivative method for LAI estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to apply innovative filtering approaches in the hyperspectral directional second derivative method for LAI estimation because the derivative method is highly sensitive to random noise. Filtering helps to de-noise data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, thereby improving the accuracy of LAI retrieval by addressing challenges such as canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind using MODIS surface reflectance data for estimating midday gross primary production (GPP) in vegetation studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives behind using MODIS surface reflectance data for estimating midday gross primary production (GPP) include leveraging its daily coverage and suitable spectral characteristics to estimate key parameters like light use efficiency (LUE) and the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR). This approach aims to improve the accuracy of GPP estimates, which are vital for understanding biomass production and ecosystem carbon dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data collection methods are used to measure the leaf area index (LAI) in terrestrial vegetation ecosystems, and how do these methods ensure accurate LAI retrieval?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection methods for measuring LAI involve using tools like the LAI3000, protractors, and rulers to measure vegetation structure parameters. Specific measurements include the maximum length and width of each leaf for crops like corn and wheat, leaf angles through dividing the leaf into three segments, and measuring segment lengths and widths. Canopy height is averaged from multiple measurements, and distance between crops is measured with a measuring tape. Measurements are recorded in Excel to ensure accuracy. These methods help ensure accurate LAI retrieval by providing detailed vegetation structure parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the canopy reflectance model utilized to improve LAI estimation accuracy in remote sensing applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The canopy reflectance model is utilized through a hyperspectral directional second derivative method (DSD) to estimate LAI accurately by analyzing canopy anisotropy. This approach addresses the challenges posed by canopy reflectance anisotropy and background variations. The method involves pre-processing the data and applying a filtering approach to de-noise the data in both spectral and spatial dimensions, thus improving LAI estimation accuracy in remote sensing applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to estimate gross primary production (GPP) using MODIS surface reflectance data, and how is the accuracy of this estimation validated?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To estimate GPP using MODIS surface reflectance data, broadband MODIS vegetation indices (VIs) are evaluated for light use efficiency (LUE) and fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR) estimation. The procedure involves using a product of MODIS surface-reflectance atmospheric correction algorithm data, selecting cloud-free days, and applying the expression VI × VI × PAR to estimate midday GPP. The accuracy is validated by the high determination coefficients (R2 values) obtained, indicating effective estimation with MODIS data.

Enablement.Question: What measurement tools or technologies enable the accurate collection of leaf area index (LAI) data in dense vegetative regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of tools such as the LAI3000, protractors, and rulers enables accurate collection of LAI data by measuring vegetation structural parameters like leaf length, width, and angle, as well as plant and canopy heights.

Expectation.Question: Why might LAI retrieval methods based on vegetation indices like NDVI have low accuracy, and what could be done to improve them?
Expectation.Answer: LAI retrieval methods using vegetation indices such as NDVI have low accuracy because these indices can easily become saturated and do not effectively account for complex background variations. Improving these methods might involve developing advanced techniques that consider canopy anisotropy and incorporate innovative filtering approaches to reduce noise and enhance data precision.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do researchers face in using hyperspectral and multi-angular images for LAI retrieval, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers face challenges such as the anisotropy of canopy reflectance, variations in background characteristics, and atmospheric conditions when using hyperspectral and multi-angular images for LAI retrieval. These factors can constrain accuracy. The adoption of a hyperspectral directional second derivative method, along with innovative filtering methods to de-noise data, is suggested to overcome these challenges and improve the accuracy of LAI retrieval.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the integration of MODIS data enhance the estimation of Gross Primary Production (GPP) in vegetation studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Integration of MODIS data can enhance the estimation of GPP by providing consistent daily coverage with suitable spectral characteristics, aiding in the evaluation of vegetation indices (VIs) such as EVI for estimating light use efficiency (LUE) and the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR). This integration allows for more accurate GPP estimation, as demonstrated by high determination coefficients when using methods like VI × VI × PAR with MODIS data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in partitioning ecosystem respiration into autotrophic and heterotrophic components for estimating gross primary production.
Assertion.Answer: The challenge in partitioning ecosystem respiration lies in the eddy covariance technique, which only provides integrated CO2 flux measurements over varying footprints. Additionally, the limitation of light use efficiency models, which require detailed meteorological inputs, leads to substantial errors, making it difficult to accurately partition respiration components.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how using a hybrid canopy reflectance model improves LAI estimation accuracy in complex background environments.
Assertion.Answer: The hybrid canopy reflectance model improves LAI estimation accuracy by considering the anisotropic effect of canopy reflectance and removing such effects while being sensitive to background variations. This approach, combined with innovative filtering methods, helps to accurately estimate LAI even in complex background environments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodological approaches to estimate gross primary production (GPP) using remote sensing data, focusing on the integration of vegetation indices and light use efficiency models.
Request/Directive.Answer: The estimation of GPP using remote sensing data involves the use of vegetation indices (VIs) and light use efficiency (LUE) models. In the provided content, the daily MODIS surface reflectance product was utilized for GPP estimation, with VIs like EVI showing potential for estimating LUE and the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (fAPAR). The methodology involves using expressions like VI × VI × PAR, which has shown high determination coefficients (R2 = 0.81 to 0.91), indicating that GPP can be effectively estimated using these integrated approaches.
